title: function lifetime elision changed in 1.64

labels.name: T-lang
labels.description: Relevant to the language team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-stable
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from one stable version to another.

body:
[I tried this code:](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=02637fdcea99e2fb9593e41df6cc3475)

```rust
fn foo<'a>(_: &'a str, _: &'a str) -> &str { "" }
```

[I expected to see this happen:](https://rust.godbolt.org/z/oK3o15oxG)
```rust
error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifier
 --> <source>:1:39
  |
1 | fn foo<'a>(_: &'a str, _: &'a str) -> &str { "" }
  |               -------     -------     ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
  = help: this function's return type contains a borrowed value, but the signature does not say whether it is borrowed from argument 1 or argument 2
help: consider using the `'a` lifetime
  |
1 | fn foo<'a>(_: &'a str, _: &'a str) -> &'a str { "" }
  |                                       ~~~

error: aborting due to previous error
```
Instead, this happened: Successful compilation

### Meta

Tested on the playground, all versions and editions.
* Stable channel: 1.64.0
* Beta channel: 1.65.0-beta.3 (2022-10-10 da7ffa2d1df2daf747b8)
* Nightly channel: 1.66.0-nightly (2022-10-19 4b8f4319954ff2642690)

### Notes

I'm labeling this as a regression as I believe it is severe enough of an unplanned change (at best an accidental stabilization?) that I should draw attention to it, even though I haven't found a way to cause miscompilation for example.  I also have not tried to do so at all yet.

@rustbot label +T-compiler +A-lifetimes +regression-from-stable-to-stable
